name: Alex Platon
comment info:
I noticed that simply by looking at either one of the graphs, it is difficult to make an accurate inference about which region has been affected the most by the virus. By looking at the first graph, a north eastern area (including New Jersey) and the state of Florida clearly stand out in the number of cases. In contrast, by looking at the second graph, we can see that regions touching the Mississippi River definitely have had a higher number of per capita cases. The difference between the two graphs is due to the first one representing the number of cases as an absolute value, whereas the second one represents the number of cases relative to each region’s population.
I wonder how the two sets of data could be combined in order to answer the question: “Which region in the United States has been affected the most by COVID-19?” Realistically, there is no simple answer, which also means that various media sources can report varying results based on their main message. The existence of such biased information has an uncontrollable impact on the decisions made on a local level. For example, claims about the situation of the virus in New Jersey are decisive factors when evaluating the school reopening plans in the state. In this way, that information directly affects me and thousands of other students and their parents.
Finally, I believe that a catchy, yet accurate headline, that captures the graph’s main idea is “Which parts of the U.S. were hit the hardest by COVID-19?”

name: Kylie
comment info:
What do you notice? I notice that the areas along the coast of the US are where most cases of COVID-19 are being reported. 

What do you wonder? I wonder if opening schools and universities at this time based on these statistics is the best decision. 

What impact does this topic have on you and your community? Living in SC and being from FL, I can see that both of these areas, along with the rest of the east coast is lit up with cases. Here in SC, while we initially felt the impact of COVID-19, it seems most places have gone back to normal operation with the addition of masks. 

Write a catchy headline that captures the maps’ main idea:
"US coastlines riddled with COVID-19"

replies.name: A
replies.comment info:
@Kylie 

It is true; the highly infected areas of COVID-19 are along the coasts (both the East and the West). Depending on the area in which the universities and schools are located, they are either sticking to remote learning, a hybrid schedule of learning, or full days of school practicing social distancing. I personally think that we shouldn't fully give in to going back to a full week schedule of school. A few days at school and at home seem to be the most successful (at least where I live, which is New Jersey). 

Although many places have somewhat adapted back into their regular lives they experienced before quarantine in March, there are still some precautions many public places are taking. Masks, sometimes gloves, and social distancing of six feet is very important and essential for each business, institution, and company. 

I think what a lot of people are forgetting about when it comes to this virus that we shouldn't take any risks. Yes, things are looking better, but as soon as we return to our normal routines, we will be seeing upward spikes across the country. This causes a delay in returning to school, delayed sport seasons (whether it's with the schools or clubs), and even businesses reopening fully. If we all work together and practice social distancing as we patiently wait for a COVID-19 vaccine to be approved to administer, we could end this global pandemic quicker than we had originally anticipated.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info:
@Kylie 
By the way, nice headline! I feel like you really are targeting the main points of where the virus is located, which is the East and West coasts. I feel like the coasts are where a lot of international imports occur and where people travel to since there can also be some popular destinations along the coast. So yes, I really like your headline!
